PC version still leaves a lot to be desired. 

I've played around 55 hours and the game has crashed around an equal amount of times as I've played in hours. Always Online, Denuvo DRM, random spikes of input latency, constant crashing, weird random lag and stuttering... I'm running well above recommended specs but this is what you get when you add Denuvo.

snippet.textDisplay: Got into post launch by playing the demo and ended up buying. Very fun game and as a veteran of souls like games I'd say is average difficult on the hardest mode. The reason I say this is because the game rewards perseverance. The boss locations are near the "bonfires" unlike a dark souls game. They also give you lacrima (i.e., souls) even when you lose to a boss. On top of that, your rarely lose lacrima against a boss because after you lose your lost lacrima is placed outside of the boss encounter.

1 less because more talents and weapons would be nice but no biggie.

snippet.textDisplay:
I agree with all these points! The game isn't revolutionary but it is FUN. Honestly it might convince me to play NIOH and Stellar Blade based on this review. My favorite fromsoft game is Sekiro and this scratches that itch better than the other souls games. I loved Elden ring but it's just too slow and plodding by comparison. 

This game brought me back to OG Devily May Cry in a way which is one of my formative gaming memories. Not even close to as button mashy but it makes you feel like a badass while also requiring you get good.

snippet.textDisplay: I think I'm about halfway through the game now, and the difficulty is all mountains and valleys, with some areas and bosses being pushovers and others being ballbusters. snippet.textDisplay: Something I really appreciate about Khazan is that the boss fights are difficult, but FAIR. Also virtually NO long run backs. Once you get to the boss, you can bash your head into it without interruption. All of them also seem to have hidden gimmicks that stagger them, etc. And they mix it up, too. You can't always parry your way to victory because elemental attacks still hurt you even with a perfect parry. So you have to mix up parrying, dodging, etc. Real fun stuff. Very Sekiro like, in a way.
snippet.textOriginal: Something I really appreciate about Khazan is that the boss fights are difficult, but FAIR. Also virtually NO long run backs. Once you get to the boss, you can bash your head into it without interruption. All of them also seem to have hidden gimmicks that stagger them, etc. And they mix it up, too. You can't always parry your way to victory because elemental attacks still hurt you even with a perfect parry. So you have to mix up parrying, dodging, etc. Real fun stuff. Very Sekiro like, in a way.

snippet.textDisplay: Loved the demo and bought the game. I would say its equal to lies of p in terms of soulslike that are above the rest. snippet.textDisplay:
Anyone gonna address the ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM?  What game are yall gonna use our precious time to play? Khazan or Atomfall? I’m on on the fence, but Lord knows us gameranx fans (“Us fans” meaning of the same age group, the OGs of modern day gaming, who grew up in the 90s)  have jobs and families with limited gaming time.   So what you gonna choose?

Gameranx  is our go-to for all of our  “before you buy” needs because we are so closely bonded and branded for life with our tastes, opinions, and choices in all things gaming thanks to our era of upbringing. Time and time again if Falcon or Jake says they like a game or hate a game 99% of the time, crazy as it seems, I end up feeling the same way.   It’s pretty cool actually how it resonates in all of us. Those who know what I’m saying know what I’m saying. 

Anyways , now this is ending up a long ass comment that was suooosed to be a simple question. 

Which game yall going to with? Cause lord knows, there’s not enough time in the day for both anymore.

snippet.textDisplay:
Playing on the PS5 Pro on max settings and good lawd this game is optimized and running sweet. For anime fans this is a must buy.

Yes the game is challenging but it doesn’t feel challenging if that makes any sense. Like, it never once feels impossible but doesn’t give you many opportunities to go ham either. Like, you have to learn the fights but they aren’t hard to learn and the game is great at letting you prepare for what the boss is about to do. It’s not terribly slow but not omg fast either. Every time you die you want to slap the piss out of yourself because you know your timing was off a hair. Not like other games where a brutal attack comes in the blink of an eye and no matter what you do you just aren’t fast enough.

I suck at souls-like games but even I am enjoying this one and can’t seem to put the controller down.

snippet.textDisplay:
What do I think?:

It's Nexon, they didn't earn my disfavour lightly. So, I'm very weary, but to their credit... This game keeps dispelling my doubts the more I hear about it and with what I see.

Props for giving a demo and not the usual damage control of Youtube'r/Twitch/whatever bullshit.

My instinct tells me this is a "dipping their toes in the water" attempt. But a safe dip that they approached correctly.

I think, I'll buy.

snippet.textDisplay:
This game looks uninspired to me, maybe because we've been getting more and more soulslike, i don't know, after elden ring these games doesn't offer enough variation to me, lies of p was great because of the art direction, and theme, this dark fantasy Pinocchio theme was amazing, and had some variations, by that i mean weapons and ways to play the game. Stellar blade was more dmc like with soft soulslike elements, so it was a bit refreshing to play, and i loved the enemy desings, the parry delay was trash tho, 0,5 second delay doesn't look bad on paper, but in action it was pretty bad, i haven't played wukong, because i was burnt out already from all these souls like games, i'm sure it's a great game, at least what i've seen from it, looked great, but this Kazan game, at least it's world, doesn't appeal to me.
Also it's a full priced game, which i didn't expect, given that it looks like and probably is a aa game, but then again we live in a world where skull and bones a full priced game as well, with over 500 mil spent into development.

snippet.textDisplay: Can't believe Falcon did not mention one of the best feature in the game! When you are fighting a boss and die.. the game gives you a *boss award * for attempting the boss fight. snippet.textDisplay: This reminds me a little bit of Remnant. I think its mostly just the colors and atmosphere. I burned out on Souls a long time ago (Dark Souls 2). The ever increasing annoyance of the bosses just didnt interest me anymore. Remnant found a wonderful balance of that, the game was a fun challenge, not an annoying challenge. Bosses were tough, but they weren't (broken record) annoying. This game, while it still seems to stick to the annoying boss trope, interests me because of all the progression systems, outside of just souls. I'll have to give the demo a try. Glad you guys covered this as I hadn't even heard of it before this video.

snippet.textDisplay: 13:46 hope this means they changed it since the demo, because what pulled me away from this one was you NOT knowing why you lost. I like the systems of the parry, perfect guard, counter attack, and all, but, at least in the demo, bosses have no visual queue on what can/should be used where, so you can't learn from it. Some moves are undodgable, that's easy to memorize, but when you get to the parries, perfect guards and counter attacks, there's nothing to telling you if you missed timed or if the attack isn't parrieable (or not "guardable", or can't be countered"), you can barely ever know if you miss timed or miss used your "abilities". So it's not just trying everything everywhere, because miss timed moves will completly mess any memorization you thought you had of what's where. To me difficulty should come with the timings and how to react, not 90% iterating through every enemy moves lets say 15, times my "defense moves" 4, just about less then 60 tries if you are lucky and fit the right abilitie with the right enemy move earlier. Idk, its weird. Elden Ring having less options, you can only dodge or parry, so the iterations a lot less, which is fair, and even guard counters there have audio queue. Lies of P, undodgable moves are red so you KNOW you have to parry or move FAR away. idk its weird. For me most of these games are about timings, knowing when to hit and find an opening. When its about CREATING my own openings through reactive defense moves, at least i should know where they go. On average for any player to have to do 30+ iterations of every enemy move and defense combination, NOT COUNTING MISS TIMING, is just wasting time, not learning the boss. Too many defensive options, and too little info given/taken from them

snippet.textDisplay:
I love these videos and find them extremely helpful, you guys do an amazing job and I don't want to take anything away from that. But the reality is I rarely have the money to afford any games at full price. Maybe I'm wrong but I feel like I'm probably not the only person out there who will wait for a new game to go on sale to buy it. 

To be clear here, I'm very aware that given my circumstances I'm not the target audience for these videos and therefore none of what I have to say is necessarily relevant. It's obviously whether it's worth buying now or not.

I'd just be interested to hear what you think a decent price point would be for a game that say is $60-70 but isn't worth that much to you. Maybe the game is decent but not great... like Atomfall or Assassins Creed Shadows. What would be the price where you would say "that's what I'd pay for this game." Or even something less specific like "I might pay half price for this, or wait for the $15-20 sale and pick it up, but not for $70.

I guess as someone who can't necessarily afford a $70 game and waits for them to go on sale, I'm just curious what you might think regarding what it SHOULD cost... assuming it's a decent game but not great. Thanks for listening. Hopefully that makes sense.

snippet.textDisplay:
For those assuming this is just another game from an Asian sweatshop studio, here’s some context:

Nexon is the publisher and parent company, while its subsidiary, Neople, is the developer. Neople is best known for Dungeon Fighter, the highest-grossing PC game of all time with more than 800 million players (look it up, if you don't believe it). 

Nexon, headquartered in Seoul, employs over 6,000 people. Neople, based on Jeju Island—often called the "Hawaii of South Korea"—has a team of more than 1,000. 

Both companies are considered among the top workplaces in South Korea and widely regarded as the best game developer in the country in terms of employee benefits and work environment. Competition for jobs is fierce, and those who make it through are among the best in the industry.

So, the quality of the games developed by Nexon/Neople tends to be top notch. To my understanding, their games are entirely developed and hand-crafted in house. Including the music. In fact, as far as the music goes, they have a large team of in-house composers, which is almost unheard of in the gaming industry. They do not cut any corners with cheap outsourcing or using generic game assets.

snippet.textDisplay: The main difference between Elden Ring, Sekiro, and Nioh is jumping. Jumping and attacking is integral and necessary in Elden Ring and Sekiro. I don't see how you can call both Elden Ring and Nioh Soulslikes. I tried Nioh and it's not like Sekiro or ER at all to me. There are numerous parts of those games where you can't advance without jumping which is how action games have been since the 80s for the most part. Shinobi, Sonic, Mario, Ninja Gaiden, Castlevannia, GTA3, Lords of Shadow, God of War, Assassin's Creed, Sekiro, and Elden Ring. You should point that out because I actually returned Nioh for that reason alone. There is no manual jumping the player only jumps during certain moves so it makes the combat seem more controlled. In Sekiro you can beat many bosses by jumping away at certain points.
snippet.textOriginal: The main difference between Elden Ring, Sekiro, and Nioh is jumping. Jumping and attacking is integral and necessary in Elden Ring and Sekiro. I don't see how you can call both Elden Ring and Nioh Soulslikes. I tried Nioh and it's not like Sekiro or ER at all to me. There are numerous parts of those games where you can't advance without jumping which is how action games have been since the 80s for the most part. Shinobi, Sonic, Mario, Ninja Gaiden, Castlevannia, GTA3, Lords of Shadow, God of War, Assassin's Creed, Sekiro, and Elden Ring. You should point that out because I actually returned Nioh for that reason alone. There is no manual jumping the player only jumps during certain moves so it makes the combat seem more controlled. In Sekiro you can beat many bosses by jumping away at certain points.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel like I'm being gaslit. All I hear about this game is how amazing it is, and ASIDE the good performance (which is definitely a plus) I don't see ANYTHING remotely interesting about this game. WHAT is the appeal of this game? It seems to suffer from the same problems that Wukong did, and everybody was mad at me then too when I called it out correctly.

snippet.textDisplay: The First Berserker Khazan is, in my opinion, one of the best Soulslikes in terms of combat system and impact! The combat system in this game reminded me of a mix of Sekiro, Nioh and Wukong! Incredibly exciting game, I have already played about 10 hours in this game! During this time, it was interesting to explore locations, improve character skills and fight with really difficult bosses! I also felt like my own skill in this game was constantly improving. Bosses require many attempts, but I was more interested in making new attempts than in other Souls because of the very pleasant combat and parry system!
snippet.textOriginal: The First Berserker Khazan is, in my opinion, one of the best Soulslikes in terms of combat system and impact! The combat system in this game reminded me of a mix of Sekiro, Nioh and Wukong! Incredibly exciting game, I have already played about 10 hours in this game! During this time, it was interesting to explore locations, improve character skills and fight with really difficult bosses! I also felt like my own skill in this game was constantly improving. Bosses require many attempts, but I was more interested in making new attempts than in other Souls because of the very pleasant combat and parry system!

snippet.textDisplay: Absolutely worth trying if you’re a fan of nioh/sekiro.  Going from the demo,I’ll definitely pick this up later in the year. Too much to play currently.  My ONLY issue was how the 1st boss is BRUTAL and ifs before you really get many options to do anything,so you are absolutely forced to get good with what you have at the time. Since only after that 1st boss do options open up.  I was surprised by that by the 2nd utterly brutal boss,how varied my options were even that early. I can only imagine afterwards(which is where the demo sadly ends.  It’s still shockingly long though overall!).  It does feel like some of the later parts of sekiro,where a boss may dominate you loads of times,but eventually you practically no hit them since you’ve learned so much,and man was it satisfying

snippet.textDisplay:
ANOTHER FUCKIN! SOULS LIKE... God damn it man lol


EDIT!

I just played the demo and got to the point where you unlock easy mode.. I'm absolutely loving it now and I will be picking this up tomorrow. Thank you to the developers of this game for adding an easy mode to a souls-like game. Every soul-like to this day has an awesome world, Great game play, and amazing lore that unfortunately I could not enjoy due to the difficulty. Now I can finally enjoy one. More souls like developers should implement this.  It's at no cost to the game and it just adds more players.

Edit 2/27
So a little disappointing... I bought the full game today after beating the demo the night before all the way to the end. I started up the full game and my save didn't carry over. I did everything even going into the demo and making sure there's nothing left to do. The old lady is there with the sword to take me to the crevice and obviously you can't do anything because it's the demo.

The second thing is after going through as level 1 again and getting to the point where I can choose easy mode or normal mode I chose easy mode and I can 100% say with confidence that the easy mode in the full game is a lot harder than the easy mode in the demo. In the demo the easy mode was a cakewalk and it was very enjoyable. I didn't even die once to the final boss in the demo. But in the full game I noticed the easy mode was definitely not like the demo version because I was getting hit a lot harder and also I died by the final boss about 18 times.

That's very unfortunate for a casual player. I made my way past viper and the next big boss so I'm making progress but easy mode ain't easy like it should be.

snippet.textDisplay:
God, I hate how good this game looks. It looks so cool, it looks right up my alley. But it had to be another fucking soulslike...
Why is every action game a brutally difficult soulslike nowadays? Why can't we get more DMC or God of War type games? I loved those kinds of games back in the early 2000s. Darksiders, Bayonetta, God of War, Devil May Cry... Now everything's trying to be the next Dark Souls and Elden Ring.

I don't want every inch of the game to give me an anyurism with it's difficulty, I just wanna be a cool berserker. Things can be challenging without being punishing so why does every action game choose to be punishing instead?

.....If the demo plays like I expect, I'll have to pass on this one. And I really wish I didn't have to.

snippet.textDisplay:
I finished the demo yesterday and it seems fun overall.
Pros:
- Ran really well except for random stutters during cutscenes (usually when transitioning between shots).
- Lots of graphic options for better customization.
- Interesting design choice mixing 2D and 3D.
- Nice gameplay loop that we all know and love.
- Has armor set bonuses for people who enjoy hunting for them.
Cons:
- The stamina bar felt way too restrictive. It only started to feel tolerable after dumping 5 whole points in it.
- None of the weapons felt fast enough for a dex build enjoyer like myself.
- The demo doesn't make a really good job presenting the spear and greatsword because it comes so late that your dual weapons are already upgraded and deal similar damage while being faster.
- The damn spirit laughing after every sentence even when it doesn't make sense is quite annoying.
- Some early fodder enemies have hyper armor for some reason which is annoying because early the healing resources are scarce.

Overall, I don't think I will buy it on release (unless I'm extremely bored). I think I will wait for it to be on sale.

snippet.textDisplay:
1:00 What's even more incredible is that this was initially a completely different game. It was labeled as project bbq and it was suppose to be a 3d mmo adaptation of the original dfo game, but due to poor management and creative differences this project went nowhere and was left to rot until the team switched course and made it into a single player action game. 

So not only this the team's first attempt, it's also the remains of a failed mmorpg. To be able to salvage your project like that and turn it into an amazing game on your first attempt is very impressive.
snippet.textOriginal:

It was labeled as project bbq and it was suppose to be a 3d mmo adaptation of the original dfo game, but due to poor management and creative differences this project went nowhere and was left to rot until the team switched course and made it into a single player action game.

snippet.textDisplay: This game is Sekiro level difficult and much like Sekiro if you can't perfect parry a rampaging enemy 20 times in a row, every time, you're going to have a very bad time. With that said, this is a 9/10 souls like they don't get much better.  The games biggest flaw is no dodge roll but the perfect dodge is so good it almost makes up for it. It's very much like Black Myth Wukong's. The deluxe edition armor is insanely good and will be a game changer for players who are getting relentlessly bodied by Blade Phantom.

snippet.textDisplay:
Love your reviews but it's weird that you mention how the the game actually takes way more inspiration from Nioh than a Souls game, which I agree with, and you say its more hack and slashey, but you then say its derivative of a souls like? Like what? 

I'm sooo sick and tired of EVERY SINGLE challenging action rpg with stamina management being called a "soulslike", it's just meaningless, wrong and exhausting. I do not thing of souls games when I play these games, not when I played Stellar Blade, not Nioh, and not in Wu Kong, they are DIFFERENT games and its bloody disrespectful and sad that all their gameplay systems and overall feel are just ignored in their own right and reduced to simply another "soulslike", yuk!
